With a newfound sense of determination, she set about making the necessary arrangements for their move, her mind focused on the prospect of a brighter future. As the days turned into weeks, the Dashwood women slowly began to pack up their belongings, each item carefully wrapped and labeled as they prepared to leave the only home they had known for so many years. en_first_half: "Had he been only in a violent fever, you would not have despised him half so much. Confess, Marianne,
en_second_half: is not there something interesting to you in the flushed cheek, hollow eye, and quick pulse of a fever?"
en_results: for though your sister's efficacious wrap might have been worth all your scorn, dead men are always at least
en_results_raw: for though your sister's efficacious wrap might have been worth all your scorn, dead men are always at least treated with respect. But when, as in this case, to a rational apprehension of the real state of things, a lively imagination is added, what can be expected? Your sensibility, which must be extreme, from a disposition so feeling and so fond of attachment, could hardly have been proof against the distress of seeing him in this state, for his attachment to you was, I know, very great. Your own, you do not deny. Will you not confess that you were not so entirely free from a return, as to leave no room for a regret which you may now be feeling, that you were not more open with him? Much as you prized your freedom from a connexion with him, how much would you have valued such an heart, and such a understanding, joined to those feelings which first made him the object of your love? I had almost said, how much more worthy of you. I had almost said it, when I remembered that your heart was not his, or at least was not his entirely. One hesitation arose from the conviction of his not being what he ought; his heart was not so governed in its wishes as his sense of honour and his sense of what was due to himself. I was very unwilling to believe him so unprincipled as to have made a jest of my sister's affections; and I could not have borne to think of your feelings. But though it was not exactly the case, yet such has been the result. I dare say you would have behaved to him with more observance, and found small difficulty in it; but not with more pleasure — more fondness. His reserve, I shall take care to respect, by not entering further on the subject here; and I wish you will do the same; but as I really believe you can have little doubt of his wishes, you will be at no great loss if you choose rather to say nothing of this when we are together, as I have no doubt but you will find that his behaviour to you will be such as to render your forbearing to take notice of it, perfectly easy. I should not have dwelt so much upon this subject, had I not wished you clearly to understand how much my heart was in it, and how deeply I must be interested in all that relates to him. I recommended him to talk to you; I was persuaded he would comply; and though his reserve, I dare say, will be a strong inducement, I shall not regret that I pressed the subject. I recommended it to him long ago, and as far as my influence went — which was not great — I have done it since; and even in the midst of that extraordinary and trying scene, which I shall never forget, and which I am sure he will not soon, I had the satisfaction of observing some tokens which convinced me that I had not entirely failed. He was more open with you than could have been wished. I have said no more than the truth; and if there had been a want of disposition on his side, or of a juster estimate of my sister's consequence in the neighbourhood, I think I should have condemned him.

en_results: on which they are. How strange this is! You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby, if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt
en_results_raw: on which they are. How strange this is! You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby, if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt the nature of the terms on which they are. Can he be so imprudent as to give a private harbour to her affection for himself, or so indelicate as to make her a confident in a passion which he must know to be regarded by her family with such strong disapprobation? I cannot think Willoughby so unguarded. It is not probable that he should be delighted with the encouragement of Miss Dashwood's preference which, at best, is all he can be entitled to. I think him more likely to want than to love her. What a triumph for him, as I observed, to engage those young ladies in his favour; he might have divided them between himself and his friend, and been equally satisfied with either! But, after all, what is it to his concern, though by her civilities to him she might have seemed to indicate a preference of him? It is evident that she was on the point of being equally civil to me, but she did not see me. For, from the moment she came into the room, her manner was all confusion, and I am convinced that, in her agitation, she would have been equally glad to see anybody else. That she was overpowered with confusion, however, is perfectly clear; for this was all the time visible enough, though I am far from supposing that her behaviour to either of us arose from any but the cause I have mentioned, and which is unconnected with any of that impropriety which I previously hinted at—a cause, however, which I shall not explain myself, though I perfectly comprehend her feelings. en_first_half: "I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes," said Elinor, "in a total misapprehension of character in some point or other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or stupid than they really are,
en_second_half: and I can hardly tell why or in what the deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them, without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge."
en_results: and I have no doubt that I am indebted for this perception to the many opportunities I have had of observing the same characters in different lights, and of seeing them in various situations. It is a great advantage to be able
en_results_raw: and I have no doubt that I am indebted for this perception to the many opportunities I have had of observing the same characters in different lights, and of seeing them in various situations. It is a great advantage to be able to form a just estimate of the people we meet, and to be able to distinguish between those who are truly amiable and those who only appear so. I have often found that the latter are the most difficult to detect, as they are frequently possessed of a certain superficial charm, which can be very deceiving. But I have also found that a careful observation of their words and actions, and a consideration of their general conduct, will usually enable us to form a tolerably accurate opinion of their real character. I must confess, however, that I have not always been successful in my judgments, and that I have sometimes been misled by appearances. But I have always endeavored to be as impartial as possible, and to consider the evidence carefully before forming an opinion. I think that this is the only way to avoid making mistakes, and to ensure that our judgments are just and fair.

I think, therefore, that it is better to say that picturesque beauty is a quality that is felt rather than defined. It is a certain charm, a certain character, that some scenes possess, which makes them pleasing to the eye and the imagination, and which cannot be described in words. It is a quality that is often associated with old and ruined buildings, with wild and rocky landscapes, with scenes of solitude and decay. But it is not confined to these things, for it may be found in many other scenes, and in many different forms. Bingley was quite uncomfortable; his sisters, however, were very ready to do everything in their power to promote the match, and soon found an opportunity of speaking to Mr. Bennet alone. They assured him that no one was more capable of giving him an explanation of the affair than themselves; and that it was entirely a misfortune that he should not have known it before. Mr. Bennet was quite astonished at their words, and wondered how they could have the effrontery to speak so; but he was too indolent to make any reply, and they were too eager to be satisfied with his silence. They were both very much pleased with their own ingenuity, and thought themselves extremely fortunate in having such a brother-in-law. Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour, reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had been insufficient to make his wife understand his character. Her mind was less difficult to develope. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented, she fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her daughters married; its solace was visiting and news. Mr. Bennet's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a-year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed, in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother's fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply the deficiency of his. Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and had left her four thousand pounds. The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt and to a milliner's shop just over the way. The two youngest of the family, Catherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions; their minds were more vacant than their sisters', and when nothing better offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening; and however bare of news the country in general might be, they always contrived to learn some from their aunt. At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the headquarters.

The more she reflected on the letter, the more she was convinced of the writer's baseness, and the more she felt the necessity of concealing her sentiments, lest they should betray her into some imprudence. After a while, she returned to her seat, and took up her work, but her hands trembled with agitation, and her eyes were dim with unshed tears. She was roused from her reverie by the entrance of her sister, who came to ask her opinion on some matter of trifling importance. She endeavored to compose herself, and replied with a calmness she did not feel, but her sister's keen eye detected the signs of disturbance, and she inquired with affectionate solicitude into the cause of her sister's uneasiness. The latter hesitated for a moment, and then, with a forced smile, attributed her agitation to a trifling headache, which she said had been troubling her all day. Her sister accepted the explanation, and the conversation turned to more general topics, but the impression made by the letter remained, and she could not shake off the feeling of indignation and disgust which it had excited.

en_second_half: to a later period—if your engagement had been carried on for months and months, as it might have been, before he chose to put an end to it. Every additional day of unhappy confidence, on your side, would have made the blow more dreadful."

en_results_raw: to a later period—and your attachment had been strengthened by years of intimacy and maturity of mind! Every consolation may be within reach. If consolation can be found, I have no doubt that time, exertion, and friendship will yet do much to break the force of the shock, and render it as supportable as it has been acute. I am rather inclined to hope that time will do much for you, and that the cloud which now darkens your prospects will gradually clear away. You are very young, and it is natural to suppose that your feelings should be strong; but do not indulge them too much, or you will suffer more. Try to divert your mind, and to find some comfort in the thought that you have escaped a great danger. You have been saved from a union which would have brought you nothing but misery, and you may yet find happiness in a more suitable connection. I know that it is not easy to forget the past, but try to look forward to the future, and to think of all the good things that are still in store for you. You have a great deal to live for, and I have no doubt that you will find that life is still worth living, even though it may not be exactly as you had hoped. I am always here to support and advise you, and I hope that you will not hesitate to come to me whenever you need any assistance or guidance. I am your friend, and I will do everything in my power to help you through this difficult time.

en_first_half: "It would be impossible to go to–morrow. We owe Mrs. Jennings much more than
en_second_half: civility; and civility of the commonest kind must prevent such a hasty removal as that."
en_results: we can ever repay for her kindness; and we have no other acquaintance who would take us in.
en_results_raw: we can ever repay for her kindness; and we have no other acquaintance who would take us in. Besides, it is so very late, and everybody is in bed. It is quite impossible. This is the most unfortunate affair that has happened to us! Such a storm to happen now, just as we wanted particularly to be off! It delays us a day, and, in short, makes a sad hole in our scheme. I was afraid you would not be able to get the horses, but I was determined to go, if all the earth was to be moved. However, I have had a very bad night's rest and have a headache, and so you must take all the blame. I should not have been so foolish, if it had not been for you; and remember, I was deterred at first, but you would not be denied; and now look what a night we have had! If we had not come, my poor sister would not have caught cold, and I should not have been so tired and miserable. I do not know how it is, but your families are so very fond of going every where! I wish we did not live quite so far from the sea; we might have gone to Sidmouth this summer after all, if it were not so very disagreeable. Not but what I am very much obliged to you for your present kindness, and I do assure you I feel it very much, I must just go up stairs again however disagreeable, and tell my sister how it is; and as the servants are by this time in bed, I suppose I must take up a candle and go myself; but I do assure you on my honour it is with the greatest reluctance. Oh! Why will not the storm clear off? It has rained dreadfully all the evening and by the pool it is dreadful. I do not know when I shall be able to get the horses; and if I do not, I shall certainly go on foot, which will be a sad thing! I do not know what to do; my sister will be so much disappointed. She is so very fond of the sea! I am sure I told you all this before, but I was in hopes you might be able to do something for us, though I suppose it is too late now. I do not know what to do, I am sure. I wish the storm may clear off soon.

en_first_half: When there, though looking most wretchedly, she ate more and was calmer than her sister had expected. Had she tried to speak, or had she been conscious of half Mrs. Jennings's well–meant but ill–judged
en_second_half: attentions to her, this calmness could not have been maintained; but not a syllable escaped her lips; and the abstraction of her thoughts preserved her in ignorance of every thing that was passing before her.
en_results: exertions, she must have been struck by the contrast between her sister's courteous reception of them, and her own very ungracious behaviour to them. But Elinor was wise enough to see that it was not for her to
en_results_raw: exertions, she must have been struck by the contrast between her sister's courteous reception of them, and her own very ungracious behaviour to them. But Elinor was wise enough to see that it was not for her to remind her sister of her faults, and she therefore wisely forbore to do so. She merely endeavoured to make her sister as comfortable as possible, and to prevent her from feeling the awkwardness of her situation. Mrs. Jennings, however, was not so considerate, and she continued to talk and laugh, and to try to make the evening pass as agreeably as possible, though her efforts were not very successful. Marianne, though she ate and drank, and even smiled occasionally, was still far from being well, and Elinor could see that she was suffering a great deal. She was relieved when the evening drew to a close, and they were able to retire to their own room. There, she was able to give her sister her undivided attention, and to try to soothe her feelings, and to make her see that she was not alone in her troubles. She listened patiently to Marianne's complaints, and she did her best to comfort her, and to make her feel that she was loved and valued. And though Marianne was still far from being well, Elinor's kindness and sympathy did her a great deal of good, and she was able to get some rest, and to feel a little better.

Aklında, Willoughby'nin yüzü ve sözleri dönüp duruyordu. Onu neden terk ettiğini, neden ona karşı böyle davrandığını merak ediyordu. Ablasının ve Mrs. Jennings'in dediklerine rağmen, Marianne, Willoughby'nin hâlâ onu sevdiğine inanıyordu. Yalnızca, bir şekilde, onu kaybetmişti. Bu düşüncelerle, saatlerce yatağında yatarken, gözleri kuruydu, ama gözyaşları, yüzünden sessizce akıyordu.

en_results: of the parties, make the censure of the public particularly galling. The world is not apt to judge the morals of our sex with the same leniency as those of men. Every man is
en_results_raw: of the parties, make the censure of the public particularly galling. The world is not apt to judge the morals of our sex with the same leniency as those of men. Every man is surrounded by women who are all, in some degree, under his protection, and to whom he is responsible for the discharge of certain duties. The breach of these duties, on his part, is always a serious offence; but the breach of them on the part of a woman is a crime of the deepest dye. The world is very apt to visit the sins of the father upon the children, but it is still more disposed to visit the sins of the mother upon the children. A man may be a drunkard, a gambler, or a profligate, and still his children are not necessarily disgraced by his vices; but if a woman is guilty of any of these things, her children are utterly ruined by the fact. This is a hard and cruel distinction; but it is one which the world makes, and which it will continue to make, until the world is very much changed. It is a distinction which presses with peculiar hardship upon women of a certain class, who are not rich, and who are not of good family. A woman of rank and fortune may do many things which would be impossible to a woman in a lower position, and yet she may escape with comparative impunity. But a woman who has no wealth, and no powerful connections, must be very careful indeed, or the world will be very hard upon her.

Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

I must be firm, resolute, and decided; I must not be swayed by my feelings, but guided by my reason. I must consider what is best for all parties, and act accordingly. I must not be influenced by my own prejudices, my own partialities, but by a sense of justice, of equity, and of right. I must be the friend, the protector, the guardian of those who are dear to me, and I must not shrink from the task, however difficult, however painful it may be. I must be prepared to meet the consequences of my actions, to face the censure, the criticism, the opposition that may arise; but I must not be deterred by these considerations. I must be steadfast, unwavering, and true to my principles, to my conscience, and to my heart. And now, my dear friend, I must take my leave. "Tuần rồi khi tôi đến đây và thấy cô chỉ có một mình, tôi đến với chủ định tìm hiểu sự thật; tuy không rõ mình sẽ làm gì một khi đã biết sự thật đau lòng. Lúc ấy cử chỉ của tôi hẳn là kỳ lạ đối với cô, nhưng bây giờ cô đã hiểu tại sao. Làm cho hai cô đau khổ thấy bị lừa dối như thế; thấy em gái cô... nhưng tôi làm gì được? Chắc chắn so sánh này sẽ hữu ích cho em gái cô. Cô ấy sẽ thấy những khổ sở của mình không là gì cả. Đây chỉ là do hành vi sai lạc, chứ không làm ô nhục. Trái lại, các khổ sở này phải khiến mỗi bằng hữu của em gái cô trở thành bạn tốt hơn. Mối quan tâm tới bất hạnh của em gái cô, và lòng kính trọng cho sự chịu đựng bất hạnh này, phải cũng cố mọi quan hệ gắn bó." es_first_half: —Ahora puede ver cómo es su carácter: derrochador, licencioso, y peor aún que eso. Sabiéndolo, como yo lo he sabido desde hace ya muchas semanas, imagínese lo que debo haber sentido al ver a su hermana tan afecta a él como siempre, y cuando se me aseguró que iba a casarse con él; imagínese lo que habré sentido pensando en todas ustedes. Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontré sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque aún indeciso en cuanto a qué hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? No tenía esperanza alguna de intervenir con éxito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana aún podía mantener suficiente influencia sobre él para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¿quién sabe cuáles serían sus intenciones hacia ella? Cualesquiera hayan sido, sin embargo, puede que ahora ella se sienta agradecida de su situación, y sin duda más adelante lo estará, cuando la compare con la de mi pobre Eliza, cuando
es_second_half: piense en la situación miserable y desesperada de esta pobre niña y se la imagine con un afecto tan fuerte por él, tan fuerte como el que ella misma le tiene, y con un espíritu atormentado por las autorrecriminaciones, que la acompañarán durante toda su vida. Con toda seguridad esta comparación le servirá de algo. Sentirá que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deberán hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupación por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deberán reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreción para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qué efecto tendrá; y si no hubiera creído muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi corazón que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habría permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narración con la cual podría sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los demás.

As she stood there, trying to come to terms with her mother's words, Marianne couldn't help but feel a sense of disillusionment wash over her. The more she thought about it, the more she realized that her mother's opinion was not only misguided but also influenced by her own biases and prejudices. Marianne felt a surge of frustration and disappointment, knowing that she would have to navigate this difficult situation on her own, without the guidance and support she had once taken for granted. As she stood there, lost in thought, Marianne knew that she had to find a way to reconcile her own desires and aspirations with the expectations of those around her, and it was a daunting task that lay ahead.

El señor y la señora Dursley se miraron entre sí, ambos pensando lo mismo: "¿Cómo podemos estar seguros de que Harry es el más alto si no podemos compararlo con su primo?" La señora Dursley suspiró y se dirigió a la cocina para preparar el té, mientras el señor Dursley se sentó en su sillón favorito, sacó su pipa y comenzó a fumar, sumido en sus pensamientos. Mientras tanto, Harry se sentó en el sofá, sintiéndose un poco incómodo por ser el centro de atención. De repente, se le ocurrió una idea y se levantó de un salto. "¡Lo sé!", exclamó. "Podemos usar una regla para medirnos". El señor Dursley se sorprendió y se volvió hacia Harry. "¿Una regla, muchacho? ¿Qué tiene que ver eso con esto?" Harry sonrió. "Podemos medirnos con una regla y ver quién es el más alto". La señora Dursley regresó con el té y se detuvo en la puerta, escuchando la conversación. "Eso es una excelente idea, Harry", dijo. "Vamos a hacerlo". Y así, la familia Dursley se dirigió al armario de herramientas en busca de una regla para resolver de una vez por todas la cuestión de quién era el más alto.

Elinor, who had been watching her sister with great anxiety, now felt a sense of relief wash over her, and she was grateful that the worst of the crisis seemed to have passed. She gently helped Marianne to a chair and sat down beside her, taking her hand in a comforting gesture. "You are feeling better now, dear?" she asked softly, her eyes scanning Marianne's face for any signs of lingering distress. Marianne nodded, still a bit pale, but her breathing had slowed and her eyes had lost some of their wildness. "Yes, I am sorry to have been so foolish," she whispered, her voice barely audible. Elinor squeezed her hand reassuringly. "You were not foolish, dear. You were simply overcome. It is understandable, given the circumstances." She paused, collecting her thoughts before continuing. "We must be careful, however, to avoid any further... unpleasantness. We do not want a repeat of this scene." Marianne nodded again, looking down at her hands, which were still shaking slightly. Elinor's eyes narrowed slightly as she watched her sister, her mind racing with thoughts of how to prevent any future episodes like this one.

en_first_half: "I am sure I should have seen it in a moment, if Mrs. Ferrars had took a dislike to me. If she had only made me a formal courtesy, for instance, without saying a word, and never after had took any notice of me, and never
en_second_half: looked at me in a pleasant way—you know what I mean—if I had been treated in that forbidding sort of way, I should have gave it all up in despair. I could not have stood it. For where she DOES dislike, I know it is most violent."
en_results: looked at me, I should have been perfectly convinced of her dislike. But I was not to be baulked in my curiosity. I was determined to know the truth, and I watched her narrowly, as she moved about the room, and conversed with the
en_results_raw: looked at me, I should have been perfectly convinced of her dislike. But I was not to be baulked in my curiosity. I was determined to know the truth, and I watched her narrowly, as she moved about the room, and conversed with the other guests. Her manner was perfectly calm and composed, but I thought I detected a certain coldness in her tone, a certain reserve in her smile, which seemed to indicate that she was not altogether pleased with me. I was not, however, to be deterred by this. I was determined to make her acquaintance, and to learn more of her character, and I accordingly made my way through the crowd, and approached her with a bow. To my surprise, she received me with a smile, and a courtesy, and we entered into conversation. I found her to be intelligent and agreeable, and we talked on a variety of subjects, from literature to music, and from music to politics. I was delighted with her conversation, and I thought I had never met a more charming woman. But, as the evening wore on, I began to notice that she seemed to be avoiding me, and that she was devoting herself more and more to the company of a tall, dark-haired man, who was standing near the fireplace. I felt a pang of jealousy, and I wondered who this man was, and what was the nature of his relationship with Mrs. Ferrars. I was determined to find out, and I accordingly made my way over to the fireplace, and joined in the conversation. The man was introduced to me as Mr. Palmer, and I soon discovered that he was a close friend of Mrs. Ferrars, and that they had known each other for many years. I was relieved to find that there was nothing romantic in their relationship, and that they were merely old friends. But, as I talked to Mr. Palmer, I began to feel a sense of unease. en_second_half: vacant; nor had it ever occurred to me that he might have had such a living in his gift. As a friend of mine, of my family, he may, perhaps—indeed I know he HAS, still greater pleasure in bestowing it; but, upon my word, you owe nothing to my solicitation."
en_results: vacant; nor had anything reached me of his views, till very lately. I can hardly think a circumstance more honourable to him, and to you, and to Colonel Brandon's character, than this whole business. It does him high honour. It gives him credit for everything
en_results_raw: vacant; nor had anything reached me of his views, till very lately. I can hardly think a circumstance more honourable to him, and to you, and to Colonel Brandon's character, than this whole business. It does him high honour. It gives him credit for everything you know to be true of him. I have not a doubt of his having been actuated by the purest and most disinterested motives. I am certain that his warmest wishes are for your happiness, and that he would not have ventured to propose the living to you, if he had not been convinced of your deserving it. I am equally convinced that he has not an idea of the living being settled elsewhere; but be that as it may, you may rest assured that I shall not in the smallest degree lessened my interest in your welfare by my marriage. I am, and shall always be, your sincere friend and well-wisher. You will have a house in town, I hope, that will be a comfort to you. I wish you may be as happy there as you deserve to be. I do not suppose you will have less comfort elsewhere; but the advantage of the town I should think must be worth some sacrifice. It prevents matrimony, indeed; but when I consider how few marriages are happy, I often think of late years, that it is better to put up with a little inconvenience, and make that an excuse for not marrying at all. I have not heard from my brother since his going abroad, but I hear from others that he is well, and I have no doubt of his being so. I am glad you are so well pleased with the place, and I hope you will continue to be so. en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."
